body: We could, and it might even have made sense from the beginning, but at this point I'm not sure it's worth it. It would make Syncthing behave differently on XDG platforms compared to everywhere else, and also open the question for what even is an "XDG platform" to begin with.

Well, glib has an answer to the "XDG Platform" question for the data dir: https://developer.gnome.org/glib/stable/glib-Miscellaneous-Utility-Functions.html#g-get-user-data-dir
Maybe go has something alike?

You could even do something like this:
- If `$XDG_DATA_HOME` is set, let's use it.
- if `$HOME/.local/share/` exists, use it.
- Keep the old behaviour. (it's probably not an "XDG Platform")

I could see something like those three bullet points work. I'd add a zero:th one before, "if the database exists in its current location, continue using that" because suddenly moving potentially gigabytes of data would be unexpected.

Apart from that I like the explicitness of depending on the variable being set or the directory existing. I personally think `~/.local/share` is an abomination, but if the user already has it they are presumably fine with it.

That zero'th item sounds fine to me. As you already stated, the alternative would have been to move the indexdb. If both directories are on the same FS, this would be cheap, but we can't know.

Well, `.local/share` sounds a bit strange, but some tools use `.local/lib` for architecture specific data. Having seen that, it starts to make sense.
Thinking about it, I like your zero'th item: It will calm everybody, who wants to keep stuff in one place.
Is it worth letting users control the location of the database using a config/env var?

That's the real question here: Should this be done?

- @calmh at least seems to be not totally against this.
- I am pro it, because it will allow me to better structure my data.

Notes:
- This is not inventing a new variable. If implemented, it would use already established variables and specs.
- Except for making the code a little more complex (it should be possible to encapsulate all of this in a small, maintainable, reviewable block of code), I can't really see, what would become worse.
- What else do we have, that is CON?

A point against this is that today I can easily launch two parallel Syncthing instances:

$ syncthing -home h1 &
$ syncthing -home h2 &

With this change the second instance would crash as despite given separate config locations they share a database location. We'd need an option for the database location as well.

$ syncthing -home h1 -db h1-db &
$ syncthing -home h2 -db h2-db &

That could also be easily worked around by doing:

    XDG_USER_HOME=h2 syncthing -home h2 -db h2-db

Of course, you could instead just have the `-db` argument override the auto-detection.

There's also the question of whether you even want to support a single user running multiple instances.

I didn't know about the `-home` option.
Another workaround would be to let `-home`  force zero'th behaviour (db inside config dir).
Yet another is to set `$HOME`.

Summarizing, I think we should do something like this;

1. If the user specified `-home`, that's where the database goes.
2. If the database already exists in the config dir (current / old style), that's where it should be.
3. If `$XDG_DATA_HOME` is set, that's where the database should be.
4. Finally, default to the same behavior as now.

Steps 2-3 are the new ones, adding some auto detection for the database location.
With 3. you mean something like the first two bullets in my comment https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/4924#issuecomment-387005073 ?

I'm not so sure about the second one of those ("if ~/.local/share exists, use that"). There is an intentionality behind setting the environment variable. The path, however, might have been created by some other program that just always assumes XDG paths, incorrectly - like, some Java stuff on my Mac, which should use ~/Library/Application Support like everything else.

That said, if there is a Syncthing database in ~/.local/share/syncthing we should definitely use that. So there is an additional point 2.5 for checking that;

1. If the user specified `-home`, that's where the database goes.
2. If the database already exists in the config dir (current / old style), that's where it should be.
2. If the database already exists in the default XDG data dir (`~/.local/share/syncthing`), that's where it should be.
3. If `$XDG_DATA_HOME` is set, that's where the database should be.
4. Finally, default to the same behavior as now.

The idea behind the original "check for `~/.local/share`" was to check for an "XDG Platform". I didn't know about those broken programs. We could in theory say "We should not jump through hoops, because others create broken programs".

That said, I think, the check for `${XDG_DATA_HOME=~/.local/share}/syncthing` is fine. It's "The user wants XDG for syncthing".

But please exchange point 3 and 4: IF `$XDG_DATA_HOME` is set, we have no reason to even start looking at `~/.local/share`, let alone `â€¦/syncthing`.

That would pretty much obviate the need for step 3 I think. I don't think we should take just the existence of ~/.local/share as reason to use it, so there's really no reason for a database to exist there without the variable being set in the first place.

Please don't.

`$XDG_DATA_HOME` has a default. We should obey that. We should not require people to set it to its default value, if they want things in the default place.

Basicly, the user then has two ways to opt into XDG:

* Create `~/.local/share/syncthing`

OR

* Set `$XDG_DATA_HOME`

before starting syncthing the first time.
*ARG* Reopening. I didn't want to close it. Clicked the wrong button.

The problem, as I see it, is that the whole XDG thing only applies to a subset of the systems in the world and it's not clear to me how to determine if any given system is one of those. If not by the presence of the env var, then how?
â€¦ by the presence of a directory, in my opinion `~/.local/share/`. But I am happy with `~/.local/share/syncthing`.

issue.title: Consider moving index location under ~/.cache/

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
Under Linux the DB Index is currently stored in `~/.config/syncthing/index-vVERSION.db`.

However the usual convention is that `~/.config` is for configuration files, not internal files with frequent changes which are rather put in `~/.cache`.

See https://standards.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/basedir-spec-latest.html

A good way to discriminate between both, is to ask "does it make sense to backup theses files"?
* config.xml, keys, etc. => yes, should go in `~/.config`
* internal database => nope (will be rebuild if lost), should go in `~/.cache`

body:
I would like to submit using `~/.cache/syncthing` (XDG_CACHE_HOME) instead of (`~/.local/share/syncthing` (XDG_DATA_HOME)

In my opinion the descriptions leaves no doubt for the database case:
> $XDG_DATA_HOME defines the base directory relative to which user specific data files should be stored. 

vs

> $XDG_CACHE_HOME defines the base directory relative to which user specific non-essential data files should be stored.

I consider the database "non essential" because if it is missing it will be rebuilt on the next Syncthing startup.
And of course, most people exclude `~/.cache` from backups and not `~/.local/share`.

Thanks
Until at least #3876 (and possibly other, similar issues) is resolved the index is *not* an expendable cache.
Any update on this issue?

I sure don't see any.

Like many other issues, this one requires someone who actually cares about it to step up and put in some elbow grease.

issue.title: cmd/syncthing: Always use monitor process (fixes #4774, fixes #5786)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age

milestone.title: v1.4.0
milestone.description:
Important changes:

- A new config option maxConcurrentIncomingRequestKiB has been added to limit the maximum amount of request data being concurrently processed due to incoming requests. This limits Syncthing's peak RAM usage when there are many connected devices all requesting file data. The default is 256 MiB.

- The config option maxConcurrentScans has been removed and replaced a new config option maxFolderConcurrency. In addition to just limiting concurrent scans it now also limits concurrent sync operations. The default is the number of available CPU threads ("GOMAXPROCS").

- Syncthing now always runs the monitor process, which previously was disabled with -no-restart. This facilitates crash reporting and makes logging behave more consistently. The observed behavior with -no-restart should be the same as before but the internals differ.

- The database schema has been improved and will result in a migration plus compaction at first startup after the upgrade.

issue.body:
### Purpose

Syncthing is now always run through a monitor process. Reasons found in #5786 and it also fixes #4774 as predicted there :)

This will lead to a >20% increase in reports to sentry (according to data.syncthing.net and assuming most apt/arch/fedora/... use some kind of service manager) and an initial spike of old reports, just in case that needs some precautionary measures.

I also took the opportunity to add logging to the desktop entry (also tested to work).

### Testing

I manually tested the following that without `-no-restart` it restarts on ctrl-c in subshell, on restart in UI and on auto-update and it does not restart on shutdown in UI, and with `-no-restart` it doesn't restart in any of the aforementioned cases.
